Hi,
The responses were invaluable. Thank you all. 
My manager hasn't shot m=
e (yet). If I don't post again you can guess
what would have happened to me=
. 

A few observations
2 hours is quite high.
I agree it looks quite high. =
Some initial experiments at actually
finding out how much time it takes to =
write a test method gave those
numbers. And, as mentioned by JBR, it is tru=
e that the existing code
will need to be refactored for meaningful junit te=
sts. So 2 hours may be
the closer to actuals. One of the implicit ideas was=
 to provide a
baseline model with 100% code coverage and reasonably accurat=
e
complexity measures for classes, so that classes can be test infected
dep=
ending on the complexity and code coverage required. 
As Bossicard pointed =
out, the final consensus in our team is to start
with Integration tests and=
 write unit tests for those classes/packages
that throw up during integrati=
on testing. And, possibly use the
complexity measures to find which classes=
 need to be tested and how much
they should be tested. 
Dave is spot on. Da=
ve, we are trying to do what you have said. [You need
to find places in the=
 codebase that
would benefit the most from adding tests and go after those =
first.]

Best regards,
Selva.
"As small as possible. As soon as possible."
=
